body:
Follow the installation guide here:

http://javascriptmvc.com/#&who=install

I fixed the old reference you found to javascriptmvc.git in the README. Thanks for pointing that out!
Excellent - cheers for clearing that up! :)

This won't work unless you're in a main controller or put an element controller on the document.Element.  A controller can only listen to elements 'within' it's element.  The body is outsite almost everyone.

if you want to listen to the window being clicked, there might be windowclick as an action, or at lease you can do :

this.bind(document.body,"bodyClick")

in your controller's init.

Please read up on controller in the docs for a better explanation.

Also, this belongs in the jQueryMX bugs, but that's ok.

This makes sense, as you want a common behaviour on the different platforms/filesystems. If you allow uppercase, I am sure some windows/virtualbox user will check this in as "working perfectly" and because some include uses lowercase, the code will break on a normal Linux (that means on the Web server, in the worst case).

Is there any reason why you provide an absolute path rather doing this?

./js jquery/generate/app mvcapp

Well, I have the jmvc installed somewhere like:
    /home/dave/Projects/jmvc
and I want to create the app in:
    /home/dave/Projects/mvcapp

From the first folder if I run:
    ./js jquery/generate/app ../mvcapp
I get a FileNotFound exception from java

So I'm using the full path, however, on Ubuntu it doesn't get created where I specify as it changes the path to all lowercase.

Works for me: 
./js jquery/generate/app mvcapp
Why do you use ../ ?
I don't want the app to be created in a sub-directory of the jmvc folder.
Why don't you want it there?  It's how most apps are organized.  I could probably make ../ work.
Btw, if you want it to work real quick, you can generate an app in your folder, move it where you want, then you just have to change the path to steal in the .html files.

I've been working with it in a sub-folder. It wasn't clear at the start that the created app would be dependent on files in the jmvc folder. My usual folder structure is:

```
~/Projects/appname/files
```

I thought that would be more logical, but I I'll rename my jmvc folder to appname and have:
    ~/Projects/appname/appname/...
                       jquery/...
                       steal/...
                       etc

Perhaps it should error/warn if you try and install it outside of the main folder.
yeah, I'll work on this sometime this week hopefully.
what is type?

I have no idea.   From the call stack, in model.js line 1277:  converter.call(Class, value)   ,   the third parameter is missing,  when it gets to "default" : function(val, error, type){   ...  }    "type" becomes undefined
I mean't what value is type.  It is undefined.  getObject(undefined) should probably be returning undefined.

that was the issue,  $.String.getObject(undefined)  returns DOMWindow instead of undefined, which caused the exception "TypeError: object is not a function" in   return construct ? construct(val) : val;
I think this is fixed in the latest version of jquerymx

...i thought I had some problem with passing an "id", but it turns out it's the "class" property. Once I changed it from "class" to something else, such as "buttonClass", the compression/build worked fine.
Thanks!

Thanks for doing this, but for some reason it can't be auto merged.  I think it may be because your other pull request I just pulled had some of the same commits.  Can you pull again and resubmit?  I promise I'll pull it right away this time.

Thanks.
this works in development mode?  It shouldn't.  Class is a reserved word in JS.  There's nothing we can do about this.
this should be reported in steal
issue is now reported in steal
withdrawn
This is an issue with steal, but we will look at it.

This is not an issue it is a change in organizing applications (read the latest guide to that here: http://edge.javascriptmvc.com/docs.html#!organizing) starting at version 3.1 and fully implemented in 3.2 which will be relased shortly.

There is not really a controllers folder anymore, each plugin (like a controller) has it's own directory with it's own views subfolder. I think the 3.1 generator didn't work properly as it mixed both the structures up, but the current master should do it properly and generate test/controllers/test and test/controllers/test/views.
Thanks for the explanation!
@jeffli can you provide a breaking test case for this?
This seems to work now.

Hi Brian.

Since I'm not allowed to push directly I opened a pull request on mxui (https://github.com/jupiterjs/mxui/pull/5) if anybody needs the mxutil RPC package (it's in util/rpc).

Totally up for it. I was thinking of using the jQuery UI CSS framework for the markup (should be easy to make it configurable of course). You said a lot of it is already in use. How would we do that with a cleanup? Develop it on a separate branch? Oh and write access to the MXUI repository would be great :)
